openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Antigua and Barbuda is primarily service-based, with key sectors including tourism and government services, which are the main sources of employment and income.
• Tourism directly or indirectly accounts for more than 50% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and is the principal source of foreign exchange earnings.
• Since 1995, a series of violent hurricanes have caused significant damage to tourist infrastructure and led to sharp declines in visitor numbers.

• In 1999, Antigua and Barbuda's offshore financial sector was severely impacted by financial sanctions imposed by the United States and the United Kingdom due to the country's loosening of money-laundering controls.
• The government has actively worked to improve compliance with international standards to have these sanctions lifted.

• The nation's agriculture sector primarily produces for the domestic market and faces constraints such as limited water supply and labor shortages, the latter caused by higher wages in tourism and construction industries.
• Manufacturing in Antigua and Barbuda mainly involves enclave-type assembly for export, with major products including bedding, handicrafts, and electronic components.

• Medium-term economic growth prospects are heavily dependent on income growth in the industrialized world, particularly in the United States, which accounts for approximately one-third of all tourist arrivals.
• The estimated overall economic growth rate for the year 2000 was 2.5%.
• Inflation decreased from above 2% during the 1995-1999 period to an estimated 0% in 2000.
• To reduce vulnerability to natural disasters, Antigua has been diversifying its economy, with increasing importance placed on transportation, communications, and financial services.
• Antigua is a member of the Eastern Caribbean Currency Union (ECCU), which issues a common currency, the East Caribbean dollar, managed by the Eastern Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB).
• The ECCB is responsible for managing monetary policy and regulating and supervising commercial banking activities within ECCU member countries.

• Antigua and Barbuda benefits from the U.S. Caribbean Basin Initiative; in 1998, its exports to the U.S. were valued at approximately US $3 million, while imports from the U.S. totaled around US $84 million.
• The country is also a member of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM), a predominantly English-speaking regional organization.
• Prior to colonization, Antigua and Barbuda were inhabited by several Amerindian groups, all of which relied on a subsistence lifestyle.
• British colonists established settlements on the islands in 1632.
• Following conflicts with the Caribs, Dutch, and French, the British settlers stabilized their colonies and began agricultural development.
• Early cash crops cultivated by settlers included tobacco, indigo, cotton, and ginger.
• Sugar cultivation emerged as the most profitable enterprise on the islands, quickly surpassing other crops in economic significance.
• The expansion of sugar plantations required large tracts of land, leading to significant deforestation of the islands' rainforests.
• Timber harvested from rainforests was utilized in shipbuilding and ship repair industries.
• The shift to a plantation economy involved the importation of slaves from Africa to work on sugar plantations.
• Even after the abolition of slavery in 1834, former slaves continued to work in conditions of servitude due to laws aimed at maintaining cheap labor for plantations.
• As the sugar industry declined, the plantation-based economic model eventually came to an end.
• Approximately 30% of land on Antigua is designated as arable or potentially arable, with 18% actively in use for agricultural purposes.
• Sea-island cotton is identified as a profitable export crop for Antigua and Barbuda.
• A modest quantity of sugar is harvested annually, with future plans to produce ethanol from sugarcane as an alternative or additional product.
• Vegetables such as beans, carrots, cabbage, cucumbers, plantains, squash, tomatoes, and yams are predominantly cultivated on small family plots primarily for local consumption.
• Over the past 30 years, agriculture's contribution to Antigua and Barbuda's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) has significantly declined from over 40% to approximately 12%.
• The decline of the sugar industry resulted in 60% of the country's 66,000 acres (equivalent to 270 km²) falling under government control.
• The Ministry of Agriculture is actively promoting self-sufficiency in certain food products to reduce reliance on imports, which constitute about 25% by value of all imports into the country.
• Agricultural crops are adversely affected by environmental challenges such as droughts and insect pests.
• Cotton and sugar plantations face issues related to soil depletion and a general reluctance among the population to work in the fields.
• In 2004, mango production in Antigua and Barbuda was recorded at 1,430 tons.
• In 2004, livestock estimates in Antigua and Barbuda included approximately 14,300 head of cattle, 19,000 sheep, and 36,000 goats.
• The same year, there were about 5,700 hogs in the country.
• The majority of livestock is owned by individual households rather than commercial enterprises.
• Milk production in 2004 was estimated at 5,350 tons.
• The government has actively sought to expand grazing space and enhance livestock quality through breeding programs.
• Specific breeding initiatives include the development of Nelthropp cattle and Black Belly sheep.
• There is a growing poultry industry within Antigua and Barbuda, indicating diversification in livestock sectors.
• In 1992, the European Development Bank provided a financial aid package of US $5 million to the government to support the development of the livestock industry.
• Most fishing activity in Antigua and Barbuda is primarily for local consumption, with a growing trend toward exporting seafood products.
• There is an increasing export of lobster catches to the United States, alongside some fish exports to Guadeloupe and Martinique.
• Antiguans consume more fish per capita annually (46 kg or 101.4 pounds live weight) than any other nation or territory in the Caribbean.
• The main fishing waters are located near the shorelines and between Antigua and Barbuda, facilitating accessible fishing grounds.
• The country operates shrimp and lobster farms, contributing to aquaculture and seafood supply.
• The Smithsonian Institution maintains a Caribbean king crab farming facility in Antigua for the local market, supporting crustacean aquaculture.
• The government has actively encouraged the adoption of modern fishing techniques, including mechanization and the construction of new fishing boats, to enhance productivity.
• In the year 2000, fish landings totaled 1,481 tons, indicating the volume of fish caught and brought to land.
• The lobster catch in 2000 was recorded at 42 tons, reflecting the scale of lobster fishing activity.
• Export revenues from fish commodities in 2000 amounted to approximately US$1.5 million, representing the economic value of seafood exports.
• The islands of Antigua and Barbuda possess mineral resources such as limestone, building stone, clay, and barite, but these resources were largely underexploited until recent times.
• Limestone and volcanic stone have been extracted from Antigua primarily for local construction activities.
• The production of bricks and tiles from local clay has commenced on a small scale, indicating limited but ongoing industrial activity in mineral processing.
• Barbuda has historically produced a small quantity of salt, contributing to local mineral extraction efforts.
• Phosphate has been collected from Redonda, adding to the range of mineral resources utilized in the islands.
• Industrial activity in Antigua and Barbuda has transitioned from processing local agricultural produce to developing consumer and export industries that utilize imported raw materials.
• The primary industrial products include rum, refined petroleum, paints, garments, furniture, and electrical components.
• The government actively encourages investment in manufacturing establishments, with most industries experiencing some degree of government participation or oversight.
• In 2001, industry contributed approximately 19% to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Manufacturing specifically accounts for about 5% of GDP and is characterized by enclave-type assembly operations primarily aimed at export markets.
• Major manufacturing products include bedding, handicrafts, and electronic components.

• The prospects for economic growth in Antigua and Barbuda are closely linked to income growth in the industrialized world, particularly in the United States, which is responsible for about half of all tourist arrivals to the country.

• The industrial park, situated in the Coolidge Area, produces a variety of products such as paints, furniture, garments, and galvanized sheets, with the majority of these products intended for export.
• Tourism is the primary economic sector of Antigua and Barbuda, serving as the main source of employment and foreign exchange earnings.
• In 1999, tourism contributed approximately 60 percent to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and provided more than half of all employment opportunities.
• According to the Americas Review 1998, tourism contributed 15 percent directly and around 40 percent indirectly to Antigua and Barbuda's GDP in 1998.
• The real growth rate of the tourism sector increased from an average of 7 percent during 1985-1989 to 8.24 percent during 1990-1995; however, growth slowed between 1995 and 1998.
• Data from the East Caribbean Central Bank (ECCB) in 2000 indicate that total visitor arrivals rose steadily from 470,975 in 1995 to 613,990 in 1998.
• In 1999, total visitor arrivals declined by approximately 4.1 percent to 588,866, compared to 1998.
• Despite the overall decline in arrivals, the number of visitors staying at least one night or more increased by 1.9 percent in 1999, reaching a total of 207,862.
• Cruise ship arrivals in 1999 decreased to 325,195, representing a 3.4 percent fall from 1998, primarily due to one of the larger cruise ships being out of service temporarily.
• The majority of tourists in 1999 originated from the United Kingdom and the United States.
• Tourist expenditures have shown a steady increase since 1990, reaching a total of EC$782.9 million.

• To address rising competition from other Caribbean destinations, the government and the Antigua Hotel and Tourist Association established a joint marketing fund to promote Antigua and Barbuda as a tourist destination.
• The Antigua Hotel and Tourist Association agreed to match proceeds from a 2 percent hotel guest levy introduced by the government to fund marketing efforts.
• As of March 2001, the Antigua Workers Union (AWU), representing nearly 7,000 tourism industry workers, described the industry as being in crisis.
• The AWU claimed that the industry was declining due to some airlines withdrawing from the country and insufficient government expenditure on tourism promotion.
• The government acknowledged limited marketing spending due to cash flow issues but rejected the AWU's assertion that the tourism industry was in a crisis.

• The section discusses visitor statistics to Antigua and Barbuda, emphasizing that the data pertains solely to tourists arriving by land or air, explicitly excluding tourists arriving as part of cruise disembarkations.
• In 2023, the number of tourists from the United States was 137,157, representing an increase from 129,521 in 2022, and significantly higher than 102,495 in 2021 and 60,319 in 2020.
• The United Kingdom contributed 68,278 tourists in 2023, down from 79,900 in 2022, with figures in previous years ranging from 48,328 in 2021 to 76,837 in 2019.
• Canada’s tourist arrivals increased notably to 28,775 in 2023 from 17,611 in 2022, after a low of 4,055 in 2021 and 15,716 in 2020.
• Italy’s tourist arrivals in 2023 were 2,584, slightly higher than 2,343 in 2022, with historical figures fluctuating between 598 in 2021 and over 9,700 in 2019.
• Tourists from Trinidad and Tobago, Dominica, Jamaica, Barbados, Saint Kitts and Nevis, and Germany are also listed, with specific figures available for some years:
• Trinidad and Tobago had no recorded visitors in recent years but had 4,250 in 2017, 3,768 in 2016, and smaller numbers in earlier years.
• Dominica had no recent data but recorded 4,153 visitors in 2017, 3,988 in 2016, and similar figures in previous years.
• Jamaica’s arrivals were 3,876 in 2017, 3,932 in 2016, and around 3,500–3,800 in other years.
• Barbados had approximately 2,863 visitors in 2017, with similar figures in adjacent years.
• Saint Kitts and Nevis recorded 2,213 visitors in 2017, with fluctuating numbers in other years.
• Germany’s tourist arrivals were 1,061 in 2023, up from 776 in 2022, with historical data showing numbers around 2,000–2,600 in previous years.
• The total number of tourists arriving in Antigua and Barbuda was 281,896 in 2023, an increase from 265,119 in 2022, and significantly higher than 169,469 in 2021 and 125,083 in 2020.

• The total tourist arrivals over the past years show a pattern of fluctuation, with the highest recorded total being 300,990 in 2019 and a decline to 125,083 in 2020, likely due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
• In 2012, the majority of visitors (81%) came for vacation purposes.
• Visitors coming to visit friends and family accounted for 12%, while 3% visited for business reasons, and 4% for other reasons.
• Regarding length of stay in 2012, 55% of visitors stayed for 4–7 days, 28% for 8–14 days, 9% for 1–3 days, and 8% for 15 or more days.

sections.section_name: Air Arrivals from the United States
openai_summarised_points: • In the fourth quarter of 2019 (Q4 2019), air arrivals from the United States to Antigua and Barbuda were distributed among several states, with the highest percentage originating from New York, accounting for 28.1% of all air arrivals.
• Florida contributed 9.0% of the air arrivals during this period.
• New Jersey accounted for 8.9% of the air arrivals from the United States.
• California represented 4.6% of the air arrivals, equal to the percentage from Pennsylvania.
• Texas contributed 4.2% of the air arrivals.
• Connecticut accounted for 3.7%, and Massachusetts contributed 3.5% of the total air arrivals from the U.S.
• North Carolina was responsible for 2.8%, while Virginia accounted for 2.7% of the air arrivals.
• In Q4 2019, a total of 10,048 air arrivals from Canada were recorded to Antigua and Barbuda.
• The majority of arrivals originated from Ontario, accounting for 7,055 travelers.
• Quebec contributed 2,407 air arrivals during the same period.
• Alberta accounted for 421 arrivals from Canadian travelers.
• British Columbia contributed 406 air arrivals.
• Nova Scotia accounted for 163 arrivals.
• Saskatchewan contributed 75 arrivals.
• Prince Edward Island had 58 arrivals.
• Manitoba contributed 50 arrivals.
• New Brunswick accounted for 49 arrivals.
• A total of 35 arrivals had unspecified or unreported provincial origins ("Not Stated").
• Newfoundland contributed 33 arrivals from Canadian travelers.

sections.section_name: Air Arrivals from the United Kingdom
openai_summarised_points: • In the fourth quarter of 2019 (Q4 2019), a total of 13,123 air arrivals from the United Kingdom were recorded to Antigua and Barbuda.
• The majority of these arrivals originated from Greater London, accounting for 5,351 visitors.
• Gloucester contributed 1,882 air arrivals during the same period.
• Greater Manchester was the origin of 1,513 arrivals.
• Hampshire & Isle of Wight collectively contributed 1,100 arrivals.
• Surrey accounted for 1,060 air arrivals.
• Kent was the source of 768 arrivals.
• Essex contributed 732 arrivals.
• East Sussex accounted for 503 arrivals.
• Berkshire contributed 378 arrivals.
• Oxfordshire was the origin of 326 arrivals.
• In Q4 2019, the average daily expenditure per visitor from the United States of America was USD 356.06, representing the highest among the listed regions.
• Visitors from the United Kingdom spent an average of USD 277.70 per day during Q4 2019.
• Tourists from Continental Europe had an average daily expenditure of USD 260.91 in the same period.
• Caribbean visitors spent an average of USD 251.65 per day in Q4 2019.
• Latin American visitors' average daily expenditure was USD 239.38 during the fourth quarter of 2019.
• Canadian tourists spent an average of USD 222.18 per day in Q4 2019.
• Visitors categorized as 'Other' regions had an average daily expenditure of USD 166.67 in the same period.
• The average length of stay for visitors from 'Other' regions was 14.4 nights in Q4 2019.
• Continental European visitors stayed an average of 10.5 nights during Q4 2019.
• Latin American visitors' average length of stay was 10.4 nights in the same quarter.
• UK visitors stayed an average of 10.3 nights in Q4 2019.
• Caribbean visitors had an average stay of 9.8 nights during this period.
• Canadian tourists' average length of stay was 8.9 nights in Q4 2019.
• US visitors stayed an average of 8.5 nights during Q4 2019.
• The estimated total expenditure by US visitors in Antigua and Barbuda for Q4 2019 was approximately USD 96,730,286.
• UK visitors' estimated total expenditure amounted to approximately USD 68,939,192.
• Caribbean visitors contributed an estimated USD 24,294,241 in expenditure during this period.
• Canadian tourists' estimated expenditure was approximately USD 21,136,450.
• Visitors from Continental Europe spent an estimated USD 15,738,743.
• Expenditure from 'Other' regions was estimated at USD 3,405,668.
• Latin American visitors' total estimated expenditure was approximately USD 1,468,836.

sections.section_name: Cruise Passenger Arrivals by Country of Residence
openai_summarised_points: • In the fourth quarter of 2019 (Q4 2019), Antigua and Barbuda experienced a total of 104,691 cruise passenger arrivals from the United States, making it the leading country of residence for cruise visitors during this period.
• The United Kingdom was the second-largest source of cruise passengers, with 61,442 arrivals in Q4 2019.
• Germany contributed 32,935 cruise passengers to Antigua and Barbuda in the same quarter.
• Canada accounted for 14,669 cruise passenger arrivals, ranking as a significant source of visitors.
• Other parts of Europe collectively contributed 7,761 cruise passengers, indicating diverse European interest.
• Additional cruise passengers from unspecified other locations totaled 7,252, representing a broad international influx.
• France was a notable source with 5,114 cruise passenger arrivals in Q4 2019.
• The Caribbean region contributed 2,088 cruise passengers, reflecting regional tourism flows.
• Italy accounted for 1,737 cruise passenger arrivals during this period.
• South America contributed 1,451 cruise passengers, indicating South American interest in Antigua and Barbuda.
• Switzerland was the origin of 1,146 cruise passengers arriving in Q4 2019.
• Antigua and Barbuda is promoted as "an attractive offshore jurisdiction," emphasizing its appeal for international financial activities.
• The country was the first to sign the United Nations' anti-money laundering act, demonstrating early commitment to combating illicit financial activities.
• This anti-money laundering agreement originated from a 1999 conference that urged global offshore financial centers to implement laws to strengthen their oversight of money laundering.

• The United Kingdom exerted significant pressure on Antigua and Barbuda to reform its laws related to money laundering, including issuing an advisory in April 1999 to British financial institutions criticizing Antigua and Barbuda's existing anti-money laundering laws.

• In response to international concerns, Antigua and Barbuda took measures to improve its legal framework, and a joint review conducted by the United States and United Kingdom expressed satisfaction with the country's efforts to address illegal financial activities.
• In September 2000, the government of Antigua and Barbuda announced that it had enhanced its surveillance mechanisms targeting money laundering and drug trafficking operations.
• In March 2009, regulators in Antigua and the United States uncovered that the Stanford Financial Group, based in Antigua, was operating a large-scale Ponzi scheme.
• The international bank controlled by the Stanford Financial Group is currently in receivership, pending the outcome of ongoing investigations into its activities.
• The retail sector in Antigua and Barbuda is primarily focused on the sale of food and beverages, clothing and textiles, and vegetables.
• The main retail markets are concentrated in the capital city, St. John's.
• The retail environment includes numerous street vendors and duty-free shops, contributing to the local economy and shopping experience.
• The government has undertaken initiatives to enhance the retail sector's infrastructure and facilities.
• A significant development is the construction of a US$43.5 million vendors' mall and market designed to provide improved facilities for retailers in St. John's.
• Additionally, a US$27 million fisheries complex has been established to offer better facilities for fish processing and retailing activities.
• An emerging segment within Antigua's retail landscape is the computer business sector, notably Internet casinos, indicating growth in digital and online gaming industries.
• The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Antigua and Barbuda, measured by purchasing power parity (PPP), was estimated at $1.61 billion in 2008.
• Antigua and Barbuda ranked 189th in the world in terms of GDP (PPP) as of 2008.
• The real GDP growth rate was 2.1% in 2008.
• The country's ranking in the world for GDP growth rate was 161nd in 2008.
• The GDP per capita, based on PPP, was approximately $19,000 in 2008.
• Antigua and Barbuda's per capita GDP ranked 64th globally in 2008.
• The sectoral composition of GDP in 2002 was agriculture at 3.8%, industry at 22%, and services at 74.3%.
• The inflation rate for consumer prices was 1.5% in 2007, ranking 14th in the world.
• The labor force was recorded at 30,000 individuals in 1991, with a global ranking of 197.
• The unemployment rate was 11% in 2001, ranking 130th worldwide.
• The national budget revenues were $123.7 million, and expenditures were $145.9 million as of 2000.
• The Central Bank discount rate was 6.5% in January 2008, ranking 57th globally.
• Agricultural products include cotton, fruits, vegetables, bananas, coconuts, cucumbers, mangoes, sugarcane, and livestock.
• Key industries encompass tourism, construction, and light manufacturing such as clothing, alcohol, and household appliances.
• Electricity production was 105 million kWh in 2006, ranking 188th in the world.
• Electricity consumption was 97.65 million kWh in 2006, ranking 189th globally.
• Electricity exports and imports in 2007 were both zero kWh.
• Oil production was zero barrels per day in 2007, ranking 116th worldwide.
• Oil consumption was approximately 4,109 barrels per day (653.3 m³/d) in 2006, ranking 169th.
• Oil exports amounted to 157.7 barrels per day (25.07 m³/d) in 2005, ranking 132nd.
• Oil imports were approximately 4,556 barrels per day (724.3 m³/d) in 2005, ranking 161st.
• Proven oil reserves were zero barrels as of 1 January 2006, ranking 99th.
• Natural gas production, consumption, exports, imports, and reserves were all zero cubic meters as of 2006-2007, with rankings around 205-209.
• Total exports were valued at $84.3 million in 2007, ranking 199th globally.
• Major export commodities included petroleum products (48%), manufactures (23%), machinery and transport equipment (17%), food and live animals (4%), and other items (8%).
• Main export partners were Spain (34%), Germany (20.7%), Italy (7.7%), Singapore (5.8%), and the UK (4.9%) in 2006.
• Total imports were valued at $522.8 million in 2007, ranking 189th worldwide.
• Major import commodities included food and live animals, machinery and transport equipment, manufactures, chemicals, and oil.
• Main import partners were the US (21.1%), China (16.4%), Germany (13.3%), Singapore (12.7%), and Spain (6.5%) in 2006.
• External debt was $359.8 million as of June 2006, ranking 169th in the world.
• The country received $7.23 million in economic aid in 2005.
• The official currency is the East Caribbean dollar (EC$), with 1 EC$ equal to 100 cents.
• The exchange rate was fixed at 2.7 EC$ per US dollar from 2003 through 2007.
• The fiscal year runs from 1 April to 31 March.
